channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-6642] enable_all,disable_all,drop_all can call "list" command with regex directly.
item.description:
created few tables. then performing disable_all operation in shell prompt.
but it is not performing operation successfully.

hbase(main):043:0> disable_all '*'

table12

zk0113

zk0114



Disable the above 3 tables (y/n)?

y/

3 tables successfully disabled



just it is showing the message but operation is not success.



but the following way only performing successfully





hbase(main):043:0> disable_all '*.*'

table12

zk0113

zk0114



Disable the above 3 tables (y/n)?

y

3 tables successfully disabled
item.summary: enable_all,disable_all,drop_all can call "list" command with regex directly.

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
This problem is because below code in disable_all.rb


        regex = /^#{regex}$/ unless regex.is_a?(Regexp)

        list = admin.list.grep(regex)

        count = list.size

in case of * regex will become ^*$ which is valid in Ruby and admin.list.grep(regex) gives all available tables.
But same expression(^*$) in Java returns empty list.


        failed = admin.disable_all(regex)

        puts "#{count - failed.size} tables successfully disabled"

        puts "#{failed.size} tables not disabled due to an exception: #{failed.join ','}" unless failed.size == 0

Even the number of tables to disabled is zero, output is "#

{count - failed.size}

tables successfully disabled".
This is applicable for enable_all and drop_all also.

Small change in above comment:
Even the number of disabled tables is zero, We are priting "#

{count}

tables successfully disabled".
Here count is total number of available tables.
Patch for trunk. If its ok I will upload patch for 94,92.
Pls check the same with other expressions? If things are fine then its ok..

-1 overall. Here are the results of testing the latest attachment
http://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/12552795/HBASE-6642_trunk.patch
against trunk revision .

+1 @author. The patch does not contain any @author tags.

-1 tests included. The patch doesn't appear to include any new or modified tests.
Please justify why no new tests are needed for this patch.
Also please list what manual steps were performed to verify this patch.

+1 hadoop2.0. The patch compiles against the hadoop 2.0 profile.

-1 javadoc. The javadoc tool appears to have generated 87 warning messages.

+1 javac. The applied patch does not increase the total number of javac compiler warnings.

-1 findbugs. The patch appears to introduce 16 new Findbugs (version 1.3.9) warnings.

+1 release audit. The applied patch does not increase the total number of release audit warnings.

+1 core tests. The patch passed unit tests in .

Test results: https://builds.apache.org/job/PreCommit-HBASE-Build/3287//testReport/
Findbugs warnings: https://builds.apache.org/job/PreCommit-HBASE-Build/3287//artifact/trunk/patchprocess/newPatchFindbugsWarningshbase-hadoop2-compat.html
Findbugs warnings: https://builds.apache.org/job/PreCommit-HBASE-Build/3287//artifact/trunk/patchprocess/newPatchFindbugsWarningshbase-examples.html
Findbugs warnings: https://builds.apache.org/job/PreCommit-HBASE-Build/3287//artifact/trunk/patchprocess/newPatchFindbugsWarningshbase-hadoop1-compat.html
Findbugs warnings: https://builds.apache.org/job/PreCommit-HBASE-Build/3287//artifact/trunk/patchprocess/newPatchFindbugsWarningshbase-common.html
Findbugs warnings: https://builds.apache.org/job/PreCommit-HBASE-Build/3287//artifact/trunk/patchprocess/newPatchFindbugsWarningshbase-server.html
Findbugs warnings: https://builds.apache.org/job/PreCommit-HBASE-Build/3287//artifact/trunk/patchprocess/newPatchFindbugsWarningshbase-hadoop-compat.html
Console output: https://builds.apache.org/job/PreCommit-HBASE-Build/3287//console

This message is automatically generated.

@Ram
tested with some basic regular expressions like t.,.,[t].*,'t\d\d\d','table' and some more also. Its working fine.
Should we also fix the misleading messaging? It should not print a message indicating successful execution when in fact it was not.
Pushing to 0.94.4

@Lars,

It should not print a message indicating successful execution when in fact it was not.

It wont happen. Messaging wise its clear only.

Looking at this again. Are we changing the meaning?
^

{regex}$ requires the table name needs to match in its entirety.
Just {regex}

(depending on how it is called) could match when only a subset of the table name matches.

@Lars

Looking at this again. Are we changing the meaning?

with patch can be yes because ruby grep and java patterns may match table names differently.

If it is not correct you can close this issue as invalid.
Thanks.
I am removing this from 0.92 and 0.94.
This looks like it could be useful but also dangerous. Would like others to ask for this feature (and try it out) before committing. Moving out of 0.95 for now.

Faced the same "issue" recently. Might be good to fix that.

Now, since Java and Ruby are not sending back the same result for a regex, I think we should the same API for the 2 filtering. To make sure it applies the same way on the list. Doing that will allow us to keep the current feature, but will fix it? Just a suggestion. Not sure if it's doable...

patch v1 is on the same line as the previous one.
removes all the uses of the ruby regex and instead uses the java Pattern, which we use in the HBaseAdmin methods.

-1 overall. Here are the results of testing the latest attachment
http://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/12628773/HBASE-6642-v1.patch
against trunk revision .
ATTACHMENT ID: 12628773

+1 @author. The patch does not contain any @author tags.

-1 tests included. The patch doesn't appear to include any new or modified tests.
Please justify why no new tests are needed for this patch.
Also please list what manual steps were performed to verify this patch.

+1 hadoop1.0. The patch compiles against the hadoop 1.0 profile.

+1 hadoop1.1. The patch compiles against the hadoop 1.1 profile.

+1 javadoc. The javadoc tool did not generate any warning messages.

+1 javac. The applied patch does not increase the total number of javac compiler warnings.

+1 findbugs. The patch does not introduce any new Findbugs (version 1.3.9) warnings.

+1 release audit. The applied patch does not increase the total number of release audit warnings.

+1 lineLengths. The patch does not introduce lines longer than 100

-1 site. The patch appears to cause mvn site goal to fail.

-1 core tests. The patch failed these unit tests:

-1 core zombie tests. There are 1 zombie test(s): at org.apache.hadoop.hbase.regionserver.wal.TestLogRolling.testLogRollOnDatanodeDeath(TestLogRolling.java:354)

Test results: https://builds.apache.org/job/PreCommit-HBASE-Build/8683//testReport/

This message is automatically generated.

Patch lgtm Matteo Bertozzi.
Its better to commit to latest versions atleast.
Thanks.

committed to trunk

Lars Hofhansl stack Andrew Purtell your decision on backporting it to 94, 96, and 98. You may consider this incompatible change if people relies on globs for "list" commands, but the other side is the problem with enable_all, delete_all operations which are operating on something that is not the set requested by the user.

SUCCESS: Integrated in HBase-TRUNK #4935 (See https://builds.apache.org/job/HBase-TRUNK/4935/)
HBASE-6642 enable_all,disable_all,drop_all can call 'list' command with regex directly (mbertozzi: rev 1570128)

+1 for 0.98. Please update this JIRA with a release note.

I was in this part of the code when working on HBASE-9182. I would not claim our shell stuff in this area is the best it can be.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue:
from 0.98.1 every hbase shell command that support regex filtering is using the java Pattern class, which does not support glob patterns.
http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/util/regex/Pattern.html
